repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:  Numberwidth may depend on number of signs with text in the
          buffer and is not handled correctly for extmark signs.
Solution: Move legacy sign code for changed numberwidth so that it is
          handled properly for legacy and extmark signs alike.

Fix #28984

comment_data.body: Should this also be done for other tabpages?

It seems so. I assumed the nrwidth cache would be invalidated upon switching tabpages but that doesn't seem to be the case.

There is also (currently `static`) `may_force_numberwidth_recompute()` in `sign.c` which could be re-used here.
Updated with a different solution that handles this properly.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -184,13 +185,29 @@ void buf_put_decor(buf_T *buf, DecorInline decor, int row, int row2)
   }
 }
 
+/// When displaying signs in the 'number' column, if the width of the number
+/// column is less than 2, then force recomputing the width after placing or
+/// unplacing the first sign in "buf".
+static void may_force_numberwidth_recompute(buf_T *buf, int unplace)

comment_regular_data.body: Setting aside my minimal reproducer, I definitely encountered this bug outside of startup: the buffer loaded, then an LSP client processed the buffer and added a mark (and corrupted the heap, because of this bug), and then I got a crash (assertion failure) on a future call to `free`.
Good to know, I can try to add a different test in that case.
Perhaps just swapping the VimEnter for a CursorHold?
OK yeah I was just misled by the involved repro in the linked issue. Exchanged for a simpler test that crashes on master with an ASAN build.

performed_via_github_app.description: Automate your workflow from idea to production

title: fix(column): crash with 'signcolumn' set to "number"
